item.title: The Looming Taiwan Chip Disaster That Silicon Valley Has Long Ignored
item.description: If China invades Taiwan and cuts off its chip exports to American companies, the tech industry and the U.S. economy would be crippled.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Ben Jones; Source Photographs by Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times; Loren Elliott for The New York Times; Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Mexican Forces Say They Tracked El Mencho to Cabin by Following His Lover
item.description: Top security officials revealed details of the operation that led to the death of Mexico’s most wanted drug cartel leader.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Yuri Cortez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gen. Ricardo Trevilla Trejo, Mexico’s defense minister, described this weekend’s operation against a top cartel leader at a news conference in Mexico City on Monday with President Claudia Sheinbaum.

item.title: After Six Decades of the War on Drugs, What Works?
item.description: The U.S. and its allies have spilled blood and treasure to kill drug lords and defeat cartels, but the drugs keep coming and the new groups are more violent than ever.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A burned car in Guadalajara following the capture and killing of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes.

item.title: After Chaos Rips Across Mexico, the Remnants of Cartel Violence Haunt Residents
item.description: Charred vehicles cluttered deserted streets as residents started to emerge from their homes in Guadalajara, which was hit hard by violence after the death of a cartel leader.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and César Rodríguez
item.media:credit: César Rodríguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Empty streets and closed businesses on Monday in downtown Guadalajara.

item.title: What Travelers Need to Know as Cartel Violence Rattles Mexico
item.description: The killing of a drug lord and the unrest that followed have prompted flight cancellations, roadblocks, cruise disruptions and “shelter in place” alerts.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Hiltner
item.media:credit: Ulises Ruiz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mayhem after the killing of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, who led a powerful criminal group, disrupted flights at Guadalajara International Airport on Sunday.

item.title: New York City Restaurants Face the Blizzard
item.description: Across New York City, restaurateurs and cafe owners weigh logistics and the safety of staff against the demands of customers and a slow winter.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson
item.media:credit: Jonah Rosenberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: After many of its staff decided they wanted to work, the bakery Welcome Home in Bedford-Stuyvesant decided to open for businesses on Monday and sold out within hours.

item.title: Snowstorm Is ‘as Bad as I’ve Seen It,’ Massachusetts Governor Says
item.description: Gov. Maura Healey said there were nearly 300,000 power outages throughout the state and about 350 cars stuck on roadways, some with drivers still in them.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales and Jenna Russell
item.media:credit: Lucy Lu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wind gusts topping 60 miles per hour and snowfall exceeding two feet in some counties hindered the effort to restore power in the state on Monday.

item.title: Trump Says General Caine Sees Easy Victory if U.S. Attacks Iran
item.description: The remarks differ from what Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is said to have told the president in high-level White House meetings.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, in December. President Trump has been leaning toward conducting an initial strike against Iran in coming days intended to demonstrate to the country’s leaders that they must be willing to agree to give up the ability to make a nuclear weapon.

item.title: What Brontë Country Tells Us About Britain Today
item.description: West Yorkshire, where the original “Wuthering Heights” was written, offers a window into the forces that are disrupting British politics.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Andrew Testa
item.media:description: The windswept area of northern England where Emily Brontë wrote “Wuthering Heights” remains a place of startling natural beauty.

item.title: These Ukrainians Don’t Want to Be Traded to Russia for Peace
item.description: Four years into the war, a major sticking point in talks is control of the eastern Donetsk region. Residents could face an agonizing choice if Ukraine gives up the territory.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Lynsey Addario and Tyler Hicks
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daria Bondareva last month with a customer at her salon in Sloviansk, Ukraine, in the Donetsk region.

item.title: How Russia Put Its Future at Risk by Remaking Its Economy for War
item.description: About half of the country’s federal budget goes toward the fight in Ukraine, money that does little to support its long-term development.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Russian troops during a rehearsal of the Victory Day military parade in Moscow, last year.

item.title: Trump Administration Scrambles to Pick Up the Pieces of Broken Tariffs
item.description: President Trump is already working to piece his tariff program back together, after a Supreme Court ruling ruptured a centerpiece of his economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has said that tariffs will help America’s manufacturing sector and create factory jobs, though many economists have questioned those claims.

item.title: FedEx Sues for Refund of Trump Tariffs Rejected by Supreme Court
item.description: The company, which did not specify how much it was seeking, is expected to be one of many demanding compensation for levies ruled unlawful.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some analysts say the tariffs ruled illegal by the Supreme Court last week had raised as much as $175 billion.

item.title: Judges Grow Angry Over Trump Administration Violating Their Orders
item.description: At least 35 times since August, federal judges have ordered the administration to explain why it should not be punished for violating their orders in immigration cases.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz, Zach Montague and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: In internal communications, the Justice Department’s leadership in Washington has taken a defiant posture toward federal judges.

item.title: Five Big Political Questions About Trump’s State of the Union Speech
item.description: Tariffs, the cost of living, immigration: The president has a careful line to walk on major issues.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Peter Attia Leaves CBS News Amid Epstein Files Fallout
item.description: Emails showed that the longevity influencer had provided medical advice to Jeffrey Epstein and had made crude comments about women.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Peter Mandelson, Ex-Ambassador to the U.S., Is Released After U.K. Arrest Amid Epstein Accusations
item.description: Peter Mandelson was arrested on Monday on suspicion of “misconduct in public office” following revelations about his dealings with Jeffrey Epstein, the sex offender.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Reuters

item.title: Texas Rep. Tony Gonzales Pressured to Resign Over Sexual Messages to Staff Member
item.description: Democrats and Republicans urged Tony Gonzales to step down after allegations that he had sent inappropriate texts to a staff member and had a sexual relationship with her.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Tony Gonzales of Texas, who is facing a tough re-election fight, has denied engaging in a sexual relationship with a staff member.

item.title: Witness Who Disputed ICE Account of Ruben Ray Martinez Shooting Dies in Car Accident
item.description: A passenger in the car with Ruben Ray Martinez wrote that the men were trying to comply with authorities before Mr. Martinez was shot. The passenger, Joshua Orta, died in a car accident on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Scott Ball for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rachel Reyes, the mother of Ruben Ray Martinez, holding a photo of her son. Mr. Martinez was shot and killed by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer last year.

item.title: Training for New ICE Agents Is ‘Deficient’ and ‘Broken,’ Whistle-Blower Says
item.description: The former official appeared with congressional Democrats, who also released documents indicating significant reductions in instructional hours for recruits.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas and Hamed Aleaziz
item.category: Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: “For the last five months, I watched ICE dismantle the training program,” Ryan Schwank told congressional Democrats on Monday.

item.title: After Saks Bankruptcy, Richard Baker Says He Saved Luxury Department Stores
item.description: Richard Baker wanted to create a retail empire when he combined Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus. About a year later, it filed for bankruptcy.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman, Lauren Hirsch, Jacob Bernstein and Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Dina Litovsky
item.media:description: Richard Baker at the Saks Fifth Avenue flagship store in New York City in 2023. The chain’s parent company entered bankruptcy last month.

item.title: Kyiv Is Freezing, but There Is Warmth, Too
item.description: Delegations from Ukraine, Russia and the United States have been meeting in Abu Dhabi for peace talks. I hear it’s warm there.
item.dc:creator: Jenya Polosina and Anna Ivanenko

item.title: New York Democrats Have a Chance to Vote Against the A.I. Oligarchs
item.description: There’s a huge political opportunity for the party that can stand up for human beings in the face of A.I.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

item.title: In Blow to Mamdani, Left-Leaning Group Breaks With Mayor Over U.S. House Race
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York had lobbied for his preferred candidate, Claire Valdez. But the party backed Antonio Reynoso, the Brooklyn borough president.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antonio Reynoso, the Brooklyn borough president, has been endorsed by Representative Nydia M. Velázquez, whom he is running to succeed in Congress.

item.title: BAFTAs Guest With Tourettes Shouts Racial Slur During Michael B. Jordan and Delroy Lindo’s Appearance
item.description: A racist slur, shouted involuntarily while Michael B. Jordan and Delroy Lindo were presenting an award, raised questions about how the show’s host and the BBC responded.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:credit: Stuart Wilson/Getty Images for BAFTA

item.title: The Japanese Airport That Doesn’t Lose Bags
item.description: Kansai International Airport, which is located near Osaka, Japan, hasn’t lost a single piece of luggage since it opened in 1994. River Akira Davis, our Tokyo correspondent, visited the airport to understand how Japanese culture has influenced its success.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis, Nailah Morgan, Jon Hazell, Stephanie Swart, Daishi Kusunoki and Hisako Ueno

item.title: Canada to Probe What OpenAI Knew About Tumbler Ridge Shooter
item.description: The company suspended the killer’s ChatGPT account over a policy violation in June, eight months before the attacks in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for the victims of a the mass shooting this month at Tumbler Ridge Secondary School in British Columbia.

item.title: Texas Lt. Governor Says Camp Mystic Shouldn’t Receive License to Reopen
item.description: Separately, a lawsuit filed Monday asserted that Texas officials shared blame in the flood disaster that killed 27 girls last summer.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham
item.media:credit: Scott Ball for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial across the Guadalupe River from Camp Mystic in October.
